description: Linguistic Bridging Inference Relations - Definitions for implicit discourse connections

relations.definition: A physical or abstract part of a larger whole

example.text: I looked into the room. The ceiling was very high.
example.explanation: The ceiling is a part of the room - requires background knowledge about spatial structures

relations.definition: A member or element of a collection, group, or set

example.text: The class was diverse. One student stood out.
example.explanation: A student is a member of the class - requires understanding of set-element relationships

relations.inference_required: Understanding of set and element relationships

relations.definition: A tool or instrument used within an action frame

example.text: John was murdered yesterday. The knife lay nearby.
example.explanation: The knife is an instrument in the murder event frame - requires understanding of typical murder scenarios

relations.inference_required: Knowledge of event frames and their typical instruments

relations.definition: A central theme or topic within a conceptual frame

example.text: The conference focused on AI ethics. Privacy concerns were raised.
example.explanation: Privacy concerns are arguments/themes within the AI ethics event - requires frame understanding

relations.inference_required: Understanding of event frames and their themes

relations.definition: Causal relationship between events or states

example.text: The storm was severe. Many buildings collapsed.
example.explanation: The storm caused the buildings to collapse - requires causal reasoning

example.text: We visited Paris. The museum was crowded.
example.explanation: The museum is located in Paris - requires understanding of spatial relationships

example.text: The meeting started. Five minutes later, the CEO arrived.
example.explanation: The CEO's arrival is temporally related to the meeting start - requires temporal reasoning

extraction_guidelines.focus: Focus only on implicit relations that require inference
requirements: The anaphor should NOT be directly mentioned in the same sentence as the anchor
Relations must require world knowledge or conceptual frame understanding
Simple co-reference is NOT bridging (e.g., 'the car... it')

non_examples.text: The car broke down. It needed repair.
non_examples.reason: Simple co-reference - 'it' directly refers to 'the car'

output_format.description: Format for bridging relation extraction results

bridging_relations.relation_type: one of: part-of, member-of, instrument, theme, cause-of, in, temporal
